summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against a defendant who was involuntarily committed to the Oregon Health Authority for up to 180 days under ORS 426.130.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Multnomah County, N.Y., alleges that, for approximately one year prior to the commitment hearing, appellant, as a result of his mental illness, was unable to meet his own basic health and safety needs and is a danger to others.  According to the complaint, during his last few days at MCDC, appellant was "highly agitated" and in restraints, and he repeatedly interrupted the proceedings by making statements that were highly aggressive and aggressive.  In addition, the complaint alleges that he was confrontational and made verbal threats and threatening gestures on a daily basis, including swinging his arms at other patients.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, however, that, in the past, when appellant was in custody, he had been brought back to the hospital a while ago and that he had refused to take medication or eat, but he continued to yell despite instructions to stop.  Finally, the court found that, despite repeated requests to be removed from the courtroom, appellant continued to be in restraints despite being told that he would not eat while in the jail, and, at one point, he apologized, stating that he "did not have the bad judgment to act in ways that make people uncomfortable."  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New Jersey today announced criminal charges against appellant.  On May 24, 2017, the Honorable Amy C. Welshhans issued an order imposing a temporary restraining order, ordering the release of all defendants, including appellant, from further violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and imposing a civil penalty of $75,000.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC, the defendants consented to the entry of a final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of these provisions, ordering disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and ordering the defendants to pay civil penalties of $25,000 each.  A hearing scheduled for May 26, 2017 was scheduled for 7:30 a.m. Eastern.  An examination that followed the examination that led to the determination of the final judgments against appellant was conducted by the Office of Inspector General of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Division of Criminal Investigation.   The case was supervised by Kelly L. Gibson, Chief of the Enforcement Division
